questions.stem: Fiedler's Contingency Model classifies leaders as either task-oriented or relationship-oriented based on their score on the Least Preferred Coworker (LPC) scale. According to Fiedler, task-oriented (low-LPC) leaders are most effective when:

options.text: Situational control is moderate
Situational control is either very high or very low
The leader has no formal authority
All group members are highly experienced

questions.explanation: Fiedler's contingency model proposes that leader effectiveness depends on the match between leadership style and situational control (determined by leader-member relations, task structure, and position power). Low-LPC (task-oriented) leaders are most effective in situations of very high control (favorable—good relations, structured task, strong power) or very low control (unfavorable). High-LPC (relationship-oriented) leaders are most effective in moderate control situations. Critically, Fiedler believed leadership style is relatively fixed, so the situation should be changed to fit the leader, not vice versa ('leader match').

questions.stem: Path-Goal Theory (House) proposes that the primary function of a leader is to:

options.text: Maintain strict control over subordinates' behavior
Clarify the path to goals, remove obstacles, and make the journey satisfying for subordinates
Allow subordinates complete autonomy without any guidance
Focus exclusively on organizational production goals

questions.explanation: House's (1971) Path-Goal Theory, grounded in expectancy theory, proposes that effective leaders increase subordinate motivation and satisfaction by: (1) clarifying the path to desired goals, (2) removing obstacles that impede goal attainment, and (3) making the work journey more satisfying. The theory identifies four leader behaviors (directive, supportive, participative, achievement-oriented) and prescribes which is most effective based on subordinate characteristics (need for autonomy, experience, locus of control) and environmental factors (task structure, formal authority system, work group). Leader behavior is supplemental—providing what the situation lacks.

questions.stem: Bass's theory of transformational leadership identifies four key components (the 'Four I's'). Which of the following is NOT one of them?

options.text: Idealized influence (charisma)
Inspirational motivation
Intellectual stimulation
Instrumental exchange

questions.explanation: Bass's (1985) Four I's of transformational leadership are: Idealized Influence (charisma—leader serves as a role model, earns trust and respect), Inspirational Motivation (articulating a compelling vision, raising expectations), Intellectual Stimulation (encouraging creativity, challenging assumptions, reframing problems), and Individualized Consideration (attending to each follower's developmental needs, coaching and mentoring). 'Instrumental exchange' describes transactional leadership (contingent reward), which is the complementary but distinct leadership style in Bass's Full Range Leadership Model. Transformational leadership augments, rather than replaces, transactional leadership.

questions.stem: Leader-Member Exchange (LMX) theory differs from most leadership theories by focusing on:

options.text: The leader's personality traits
The unique dyadic relationship between a leader and each individual subordinate
The leader's behavior averaged across all subordinates
The organizational structure and hierarchy

questions.explanation: LMX theory (Graen & Uhl-Bien, 1995) uniquely focuses on the dyadic relationship between leader and each follower. Leaders develop different quality relationships with different subordinates: high-LMX members (in-group) receive more attention, resources, and trust, while low-LMX members (out-group) receive standard role-defined treatment. Research shows high-LMX quality is associated with higher performance, satisfaction, commitment, and lower turnover. LMX quality develops through role-making processes over time. This contrasts with average leadership style approaches that assume the leader treats all subordinates the same.

questions.stem: Hersey and Blanchard's Situational Leadership Theory proposes that the appropriate leadership style depends on the followers':

options.text: Personality type as measured by the MBTI
Readiness level (combination of ability and willingness)
Intelligence quotient
Seniority and tenure in the organization

questions.explanation: Hersey and Blanchard's Situational Leadership Theory matches leader behavior (task behavior and relationship behavior) to follower readiness—the extent to which followers have the ability (knowledge, skill, experience) and willingness (confidence, commitment, motivation) to accomplish a specific task. Four styles map to four readiness levels: Telling (high task, low relationship) for low readiness; Selling (high task, high relationship) for moderate readiness; Participating (low task, high relationship) for moderate-high readiness; Delegating (low task, low relationship) for high readiness. Despite its intuitive appeal and popularity in training, empirical support for the model is limited.

questions.stem: Research on transformational leadership has consistently found which of the following outcomes? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Higher follower satisfaction and motivation
Greater organizational commitment
Enhanced follower creativity and innovation
Guaranteed organizational profitability
Followers' willingness to exert extra effort beyond expectations

questions.explanation: Meta-analyses of transformational leadership (Judge & Piccolo, 2004; Wang et al., 2011) consistently demonstrate positive effects on: follower satisfaction and motivation (A), organizational commitment (B), creativity and innovation through intellectual stimulation (C), and extra effort beyond formal requirements (E). However, research does not show that transformational leadership guarantees profitability (D)—the relationship with objective organizational performance is more complex and depends on many contextual factors. Transformational leadership's effects are strongest on follower attitudes and discretionary effort.

questions.stem: According to the Ohio State leadership studies, the two primary dimensions of leader behavior are:

options.text: Initiating structure—defining roles, establishing procedures, and organizing work
Consideration—showing concern for followers' welfare, warmth, and mutual trust
Charisma—inspiring followers through personal magnetism
The two dimensions are independent, not opposite ends of one continuum
Coercion—using punishment and threats to ensure compliance

questions.explanation: The Ohio State Leadership Studies (Fleishman, Harris, & Burtt, 1950s) identified two independent dimensions: Initiating Structure (task-oriented—defining roles, establishing procedures, planning, coordinating) and Consideration (relationship-oriented—showing warmth, trust, respect for subordinates' ideas). A critical finding is that these dimensions are independent (D)—a leader can be high on both, low on both, or any combination. This contrasted with the earlier assumption that task and relationship orientations were opposite poles of one dimension. The University of Michigan studies found parallel dimensions: production-centered and employee-centered leadership.

questions.stem: Authentic leadership theory proposes that effective leaders demonstrate which core characteristics? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Self-awareness—accurate understanding of one's values, strengths, and weaknesses
Relational transparency—sharing one's true self with others
Balanced processing—objectively analyzing relevant data before making decisions
Internalized moral perspective—self-regulated behavior guided by internal values
Strategic deception—presenting different personas to different audiences

questions.explanation: Authentic leadership (Avolio & Gardner, 2005; Walumbwa et al., 2008) comprises four components: Self-awareness—knowing one's values, emotions, motives, and impact on others. Relational transparency—presenting one's genuine self rather than a false front. Balanced processing—soliciting and considering different viewpoints objectively. Internalized moral perspective—behavior guided by internal moral standards rather than external pressures. Strategic deception (E) is the antithesis of authentic leadership. Research links authentic leadership to follower trust, engagement, well-being, and organizational citizenship behaviors.

questions.stem: Which of the following are propositions of Implicit Leadership Theory (ILT)? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: People hold cognitive prototypes of what a leader should be like
Leaders are perceived as more effective when they match followers' implicit leadership prototypes
Leadership perceptions are partly in the eye of the beholder
Leadership prototypes are identical across all cultures
These cognitive schemas influence leader emergence and effectiveness evaluations

questions.explanation: Implicit Leadership Theory (Lord, Foti, & De Vader, 1984) proposes that: people hold cognitive prototypes (schemas) of ideal leaders (A); leaders matching these prototypes are perceived as more effective (B); leadership perception is partly a cognitive construction by observers (C); and these schemas influence both who emerges as a leader and how effective they're judged to be (E). Leadership prototypes vary across cultures (D is incorrect)—the GLOBE project (House et al., 2004) found both universal and culturally contingent attributes. For example, integrity is universally valued, but participative leadership is valued more in some cultures than others.

questions.stem: Servant leadership (Greenleaf) is characterized by which of the following priorities? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: The leader's primary motivation is to serve followers' needs first
Emphasis on follower growth, development, and empowerment
Community building and stewardship of organizational resources
Prioritizing the leader's personal advancement above all else
Ethical behavior and concern for the well-being of all stakeholders

questions.explanation: Greenleaf's (1977) servant leadership reverses the traditional leadership paradigm—the leader's primary role is to serve followers and the community. Key characteristics: putting followers' needs first (A), fostering growth and empowerment (B), building community and acting as stewards (C), and maintaining ethical responsibility to all stakeholders (E). Personal advancement (D) is contrary to servant leadership's ethos. Research links servant leadership to follower trust, organizational citizenship behaviors, and performance, particularly in organizations valuing people development. The 'best test' is whether those served grow as persons and become more autonomous.

questions.stem: Match each leadership theory to its primary classification:

columns.text: Trait theory—leader effectiveness depends on personal characteristics
Behavioral theory—effectiveness depends on what leaders do
Contingency theory—effectiveness depends on leader-situation match
Neocharismatic/inspirational theory—effectiveness through vision and inspiration

questions.explanation: The Great Man/trait approach (Stogdill, Mann) focused on identifying traits that distinguish leaders from non-leaders. Ohio State studies shifted to observable behaviors (initiating structure and consideration). Fiedler's contingency model matched leadership style to situational control (leader-member relations, task structure, position power). Bass's transformational leadership belongs to the neocharismatic approach—emphasizing vision, inspiration, and fundamental changes in followers' values and aspirations. This progression reflects the field's evolution from 'who leaders are' to 'what leaders do' to 'when which style works' to 'how leaders transform.'

questions.stem: Match each Path-Goal Theory leader behavior to the situation where it is most effective:

columns.text: Ambiguous, unstructured tasks where followers need guidance
Stressful, boring, or hazardous tasks where followers need emotional support
When followers desire autonomy and have high need for control
Challenging tasks where followers need high expectations and confidence

questions.explanation: Path-Goal Theory prescribes leader behavior based on what followers and the situation need: Directive leadership clarifies expectations and procedures—most valuable when tasks are ambiguous and followers lack experience. Supportive leadership provides warmth and concern—most valuable during stressful or unpleasant tasks. Participative leadership consults followers—most effective when followers are experienced, desire autonomy, and have internal locus of control. Achievement-oriented leadership sets challenging goals and expresses confidence—effective with complex, challenging tasks where followers need to stretch. The key principle is supplementation—providing what's missing.

questions.stem: For each leadership approach, select ALL propositions that it makes:

columns.text: Inspires followers to transcend self-interest for the organization
Avoids making decisions and abdicates responsibility
Stimulates followers intellectually to challenge assumptions
Provides individualized consideration for each follower

questions.explanation: Bass's Full Range Leadership Model: Transformational leadership inspires followers to transcend self-interest (col2), stimulates creativity (col4), and provides individualized consideration (col5)—along with idealized influence and inspirational motivation. Transactional leadership uses contingent reward (clarifying expectations and providing rewards for meeting them) and management-by-exception (intervening only when standards aren't met) (col1). Laissez-faire leadership is the avoidance of leadership—abdicating responsibility, avoiding decisions, and being absent when needed (col3). Research shows laissez-faire is the least effective, transactional provides a necessary foundation, and transformational produces the best outcomes.

questions.stem: For each contingency leadership theory, select ALL situational factors it considers:
questions.explanation: Fiedler considers three situational factors: leader-member relations, task structure, and position power—combined to determine overall situational favorability. Path-Goal Theory considers task characteristics (structure, complexity) and subordinate characteristics (experience, locus of control, need for autonomy). Hersey & Blanchard focus primarily on follower readiness—the combination of ability and willingness for a specific task. Each theory prescribes different optimal leadership behaviors based on its situational factors. Fiedler recommends changing the situation; the others recommend changing leadership behavior.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about transformational and transactional leadership:

Bass distinguished between transformational leadership, which [BLANK1] followers' values and aspirations, and transactional leadership, which is based on [BLANK2] between leader and follower. The Four I's of transformational leadership are idealized influence, inspirational motivation, intellectual stimulation, and [BLANK3]. Transactional leadership operates through contingent reward (clarifying expectations and rewarding performance) and [BLANK4] (correcting deviations from standards). Bass proposed that transformational leadership has an [BLANK5] effect—it enhances the effects of transactional leadership rather than replacing it.
questions.explanation: Bass's Full Range Leadership Model: Transformational leadership fundamentally transforms followers' values and aspirations. Transactional leadership is based on exchange (performance for rewards). The Four I's: Idealized Influence, Inspirational Motivation, Intellectual Stimulation, and Individualized Consideration. Transactional components: contingent reward and management-by-exception (active: monitoring and correcting; passive: intervening only after problems are evident). The augmentation effect means transformational leadership builds on a transactional foundation—without clear expectations and fair rewards, inspiration alone is insufficient.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about Leader-Member Exchange (LMX) theory:

LMX theory proposes that leaders develop [BLANK1] relationships with different subordinates. High-quality LMX relationships are characterized by mutual trust, respect, and [BLANK2]. Members with high-quality LMX are often part of the leader's [BLANK3] and receive greater access to resources, information, and support. LMX relationships develop through a [BLANK4] process in which early interactions shape the trajectory of the relationship. Research has found that high LMX quality is associated with higher job [BLANK5], commitment, and performance, and lower turnover intentions.
questions.explanation: LMX theory (Graen & Uhl-Bien): Leaders develop differentiated relationships with each subordinate. High-quality LMX involves trust, respect, and mutual obligation (going beyond formal job requirements). In-group members receive more resources and opportunities. The role-making process involves three stages: role-taking (early testing), role-making (developing the relationship through exchanges), and role-routinization (establishing a stable pattern). Meta-analyses consistently show high LMX predicts satisfaction, commitment, performance, and reduced turnover. Ethical concerns include the potential for in-group favoritism.

questions.stem: A new department head is known for articulating a compelling vision, intellectually challenging team members, and personally mentoring each employee. However, the team has been underperforming because basic expectations about deadlines, quality standards, and accountability are unclear.
questions.centerQuestion: What leadership concept best explains why this highly inspirational leader is not achieving results?

options.text: Idealized influence through personal example and vision
Intellectual stimulation that challenges conventional thinking
Individualized consideration through personal mentoring
Clear contingent rewards and performance expectations
Transactional foundation—clear expectations, contingent rewards, and accountability
Management-by-exception to monitor and correct deviations
More inspirational vision and charisma
Initiating structure that defines roles and establishes procedures

centerOptions.text: Failure to build a transactional foundation (augmentation effect not possible without a base)
Leadership is irrelevant to team performance

questions.explanation: Bass's augmentation hypothesis states that transformational leadership enhances (augments) the effects of transactional leadership—but it cannot replace it entirely. This leader provides strong transformational behaviors (vision, intellectual stimulation, individualized consideration) but lacks the transactional foundation (clear expectations, contingent rewards, accountability). Without basic structure and exchange relationships, inspiration alone doesn't translate to performance. The solution is adding initiating structure and transactional behaviors to the existing transformational approach—not replacing inspiration, but grounding it in clear expectations.

questions.stem: A mid-level manager treats her team of 12 very differently. Three employees receive high-profile assignments, mentoring, and flexibility, while the remaining nine get standard instructions and minimal interaction. The nine less-favored employees report lower satisfaction and are beginning to show signs of withdrawal.
questions.centerQuestion: What leadership theory best explains this differential treatment pattern and its consequences?

options.text: Early interactions created expectations about each subordinate's competence
The leader developed higher trust and obligation with some subordinates
Role-making process naturally produced in-group and out-group members
The organization requires leaders to treat all subordinates identically
Out-group members may reduce effort and commitment (equity theory)
The leader should work to develop higher-quality LMX with all members where possible
This pattern is optimal and requires no intervention
Differentiation can create perceptions of unfairness and reduce team cohesion

questions.explanation: LMX theory directly explains this pattern: the leader has developed high-quality LMX with three in-group members and lower-quality LMX with nine out-group members. This differentiation arose through the role-making process—early interactions established expectations that became self-fulfilling. Consequences include: out-group withdrawal (equity theory predicts reduced effort when exchanges feel unfair), reduced team cohesion, and potential for resentment. LMX Leadership Making theory (Graen & Uhl-Bien) recommends that leaders work to develop high-quality relationships with all subordinates rather than maintaining differential treatment.

questions.stem: A leadership researcher is reviewing key principles. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Fiedler's contingency model recommends that leaders change their style to fit the situation. (B) Path-Goal Theory is grounded in expectancy theory and proposes that leaders should clarify the path to goals and make the journey satisfying. (C) The Ohio State studies found that initiating structure and consideration are independent dimensions, not opposite ends of one continuum. (D) Trait theories of leadership have been completely abandoned because traits have no relationship to leadership. (E) Transformational leadership has been shown to augment, not replace, the effects of transactional leadership. (F) Charismatic leadership is always positive and never has a 'dark side.'
questions.explanation: Accurate: (B) Path-Goal Theory is explicitly based on expectancy theory (Vroom). (C) Ohio State's key finding was independence of structure and consideration. (E) Bass's augmentation hypothesis is well-supported. Incorrect: (A) Fiedler believed leadership style is relatively fixed, so the situation should be changed to fit the leader ('leader match')—not the other way around. (D) Trait approaches have been revised, not abandoned—meta-analyses (Judge et al., 2002) show traits like extraversion, conscientiousness, and openness predict leadership emergence and effectiveness. (F) Charismatic leadership can have a 'dark side'—personalized charisma (serving the leader's interests) can be destructive (Conger & Kanungo; Howell & Avolio).

questions.stem: An organizational consultant is evaluating leadership development options. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) 360-degree feedback provides leaders with multi-source perspective on their behavior from supervisors, peers, and subordinates. (B) Coaching and mentoring are individual-level leadership development interventions that have received research support. (C) Leadership development is identical to leader development—the terms are interchangeable. (D) LMX theory suggests that leaders should work to develop high-quality relationships with all subordinates, not just a select few. (E) Emotional intelligence has been proposed as an important component of effective leadership. (F) Action learning combines real-world problem-solving with reflection and learning in leadership development. (G) Authentic leadership proposes that leaders should present different personalities to different audiences.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) 360-degree feedback provides multi-source data. (B) Coaching and mentoring are supported leadership development methods. (D) LMX Leadership Making recommends expanding high-quality relationships to all subordinates. (F) Action learning (Revans) combines solving real organizational problems with structured reflection. Incorrect: (C) Day (2000) distinguished leader development (individual capacity) from leadership development (social/relational capacity)—they are not identical. (E) While accurate as a proposition, it was less clearly stated—emotional intelligence's role is debated but proposed. (G) Authentic leadership emphasizes relational transparency, the opposite of presenting different personas.

questions.stem: Arrange the historical evolution of leadership theories in chronological order:

options.text: Contingency approaches (Fiedler, House, Hersey & Blanchard)
Trait approaches (Great Man Theory, Stogdill's trait research)
Neocharismatic/transformational approaches (Burns, Bass)
Behavioral approaches (Ohio State, Michigan studies)
Contemporary approaches (authentic, servant, complexity leadership)

questions.explanation: Leadership theory evolved chronologically: (1) Trait approaches (early 1900s-1940s)—identifying characteristics of great leaders. (2) Behavioral approaches (1940s-1960s)—Ohio State and Michigan studies identified leader behaviors rather than traits. (3) Contingency approaches (1960s-1980s)—Fiedler (1967), House (1971), Hersey & Blanchard (1969) matched leadership to situations. (4) Neocharismatic/transformational (1970s-present)—Burns (1978), Bass (1985) focused on inspiring followers. (5) Contemporary (1990s-present)—authentic, servant, ethical, complexity, and shared leadership. Each wave addressed limitations of the previous approach.

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of LMX relationship development in correct sequence (Graen & Uhl-Bien):

options.text: Role-making: Expanding beyond formal roles through mutual exchange and testing
Role-routinization: Stable, mature exchange pattern established
Stranger phase: Formal, contractual interactions based on job description
Partnership: High-quality, mature exchange characterized by trust and mutual obligation

questions.explanation: Graen and Uhl-Bien's (1995) Leadership Making model describes LMX development: (1) Stranger phase—interactions are purely contractual and role-bound, exchanges are economic. (2) Role-making (Acquaintance)—leader and member test each other beyond formal roles, exchanges include some social/emotional elements. (3) Role-routinization—a stable pattern emerges as the relationship becomes predictable. (4) Partnership (Maturity)—the highest quality, characterized by deep trust, reciprocal influence, mutual obligation, and exchanges that are largely emotional and relationship-based. Not all relationships progress through all stages.

questions.stem: Review meta-analytic data on the correlations between leadership styles and various outcomes:

questions.question: What do these data reveal about the relative effectiveness of the three leadership styles?

options.text: All three styles are equally effective
Transformational leadership shows the strongest positive relationships, contingent reward is positive but weaker, and laissez-faire is consistently negative
Laissez-faire produces the best outcomes
Transactional leadership is more effective than transformational

questions.question: Why is the transformational-performance correlation (.27) notably lower than the transformational-satisfaction correlation (.58)?

options.text: Transformational leadership has no effect on performance
Performance is multiply determined—leadership is one of many factors; attitudinal outcomes are more directly influenced by leadership
The data are unreliable
Satisfaction is easier to measure than performance

questions.explanation: Meta-analytic findings (Judge & Piccolo, 2004): Transformational leadership shows the strongest positive correlations with all outcomes, particularly follower attitudes (satisfaction r = .58). Contingent reward shows positive but weaker relationships—it provides a necessary foundation. Laissez-faire shows consistent negative correlations—absence of leadership is harmful. The weaker performance correlation reflects that objective performance depends on many factors beyond leadership (resources, market, technology), while attitudinal outcomes are more directly influenced by leader behavior. This supports the augmentation effect—transformational builds on transactional.

questions.stem: Examine data on how leader behaviors affect outcomes under different conditions of task structure:

questions.question: These data are most consistent with which leadership theory?

options.text: Great Man Theory—traits determine effectiveness regardless of situation
Path-Goal Theory—leader behavior should supplement what the situation lacks
Transformational leadership—inspiration always produces satisfaction
LMX theory—relationship quality determines satisfaction

questions.question: Why does directive leadership become less satisfying as task structure increases?

options.text: It becomes redundant and perceived as controlling when the task already provides clear guidance
Employees prefer no leadership under any conditions
Directive leadership is always dissatisfying
Task structure has no effect on leadership perceptions

questions.explanation: These data directly support House's Path-Goal Theory. Directive leadership is satisfying when tasks are unstructured (providing needed guidance) but becomes dissatisfying when tasks are highly structured (perceived as redundant, micromanaging, and controlling). Supportive leadership shows the opposite pattern—it's more appreciated when tasks are already structured (providing emotional support that the task context doesn't supply). This illustrates the supplementation principle: effective leadership provides what the environment lacks. When the task already provides structure, additional direction is perceived as unnecessary control.

questions.stem: Categorize each leadership characteristic or behavior according to the theory it primarily represents:

items.text: Putting followers' needs first and fostering their growth
Balanced processing of information before decisions
Clarifying role expectations and rewarding compliance

questions.explanation: Transformational: Idealized influence/inspiration and intellectual stimulation are two of the Four I's. Transactional: Contingent reward and management-by-exception focus on exchange relationships and compliance. Servant: Prioritizing followers' needs and community building reflect Greenleaf's service-first orientation. Authentic: Self-awareness, relational transparency, and balanced processing are core components (along with internalized moral perspective). These approaches are not mutually exclusive—a leader can demonstrate characteristics of multiple approaches—but each represents a distinct theoretical emphasis.

questions.stem: Categorize each leadership trait or skill according to its classification in leadership research:

categories.label: Big Five Personality Traits Linked to Leadership

questions.explanation: Big Five traits linked to leadership (Judge et al., 2002 meta-analysis): Extraversion (strongest predictor of leadership emergence), conscientiousness, and openness to experience. Cognitive capacities: General intelligence predicts leader effectiveness (Judge et al., 2004), and creative thinking helps with complex problem-solving. Emotional/social competencies: Emotional intelligence and social perceptiveness help leaders manage relationships and understand followers. Character factors: Ethical behavior and trustworthiness are foundational to leadership credibility. Modern leadership research takes a multi-dimensional approach, recognizing that different traits predict different aspects of leadership.
